required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Sensory Integration Versus Fine Motor Intervention in Children With Autism
clinical_study.official_title: Therapeutic Outcomes of Sensory Integration Versus Fine Motor Intervention in Children With Autism

brief_summary.textblock: Clinically, infants with Autism spectrum often display gross motor delays in supine, prone, and sitting skills in their first year of life. Delay in crawling, walking, and achieving other motor milestones are frequently observed in toddler hood. In addition, difficulties in fine motor skills are frequent in individuals with Autism spectrum.

detailed_description.textblock: Many studies demonstrated that improvements in sensory-motor skills, motor planning, and reading related skills in children with learning and intellectual disabilities were seen using sensory integration and fine motor intervention. However, there are limited studies investigating the effectiveness of sensory integration/occupational therapy on autistic features (stereotype movement, communication, and social interaction). Fine motor skills and quality of life of children with Autism spectrum are markedly affected which might be related to the stereotype movement and limited social interactions. Therefore, this study will be conducted to investigate and compare between the therapeutic outcomes of sensory SI and fine motor intervention on autistic features, fine motor skills and quality of life of children with Autism spectrum.

primary_outcome.description: Items on the developmental sub scale address behaviors and milestones in the first 36 months of life. The four sub scales are summed to provide an autism index. The higher the autism index, the higher the probability the individual has autism and the more severe the autistic behavior

secondary_outcome.description: Fine manual control domain will be assessed in the current study. The fine manual control domains contain two sub tests fine motor precision and fine motor integration. Total motor composite and subtest measures are available as a raw score, standard score, percentile rank and descriptive category ("well below average", "below average', "average" above average and "well above average"). Gender specific norms were used for scoring as the scale's authors report these as being more accurate than combined gender norms

secondary_outcome.measure: Pediartic Quality of life Inventory Scale
secondary_outcome.description: The Arabic version of Pediatric Quality of life Inventory Scale will be used to assess quality of life of children in this study. for ease of interpret ability, items are reversed scored and linearly transformed to a 0-100 scale, so that higher scores indicate better performance. To reverse score, transform the 0-4 scale items to 0-100 as follows: 0-100, 1=75, 2= 50, 3= 25 and 4= 0. Finally, the Scale Score for each dimension and Total Scale Score were calculated

arm_group.description: children in this group will receive conventional program including stretching and strengthening exercise in addition to exercises to enhance fine motor skills for one hour for each child, three times per week along a period of three months

Children in this group will receive designed sensory integration program, one hour for each child, three times per week along a period of three months. The program includes tactile, vestibular and proprioceptive stimulation and heavy work activities in addition to fine motor skills.

intervention.description: stretching and strengthening exercises in addition to exercises to enhance fine motor skills
intervention.other_name: stretching and strengthening exercises in addition to exercises to enhance fine motor skills

intervention.description: Tactile stimulation Proprioceptive stimulation The fine motor skills Heavy work activities (i.e., proprioceptive input)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age ranges from 8 to 12 years.
- Mild to moderate autistic features according Gilliam autism rating scale: (scores from 60 to 110).
- Mild to moderate mental retardation (IQ of 35-70).
- Can understand and follow simple instructions.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Significant visual or auditory defects.
- History of cerebral palsy or psychiatric disorder (e.g attention deficit hyperactivity disorder).
- History of surgical interference or fractures of the upper limbs in the last 12 months.

facility.name: faculty of physical therapy, Cairo university

responsible_party.investigator_title: Amira Abd-elmonem, assist Prof. Physiacl therapy for pediatric department, faculty of physical therapy , Cairo university
